Description: Rim sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery kotyle with handle root; glaze fired red-brown; interior glazed; exterior, from top: narrow black band at rim; frieze of short vertical wavy lines; two bands; black-figure decoration consisting of possible bird's tail feathers, to left, above perhaps part of a panther's back; incised splinter rosette as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Probably a right-facing panther, with part of head at break.
Bibliographic references: Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 227, no. 134)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.234) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4663 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
